[[Great Lands]] | affiliation=[[Aulë]] (formerly) | language= | notablefor= | siblings= | spouse= | gender=Male | height= | hair= | eyes= | clothing= | weapons= | steed= }} '''Velindo''' was a [[Fays|fay]] of [[Aulë]]'s folk, according to the early version of the [[legendarium]] associated with ''[[The Book of Lost Tales]]''. == History == Velindo was sent by [[Aulë]] into the [[Middle-earth|world]] in order to fetch "some of the good heavy red gold of the [[dwarves]]". However, there he grew prideful due to the adoration of the Dwarves and [[Men]] owing to his skills as a craftsman. Therefore, he never returned to Aulë, but rather set up on his own - and he grew famous, but as the [[Elves]] faded so did his own power and fame, yet he never became wicked. Ages later, the mariner [[Eriol]] asked [[Rúmil (elf of Tirion)#Other versions of the legendarium|Rúmil]], an Elf of [[Tol Eressëa]], if the person of [[wikipedia:Wayland the Smith|Wéland]] (a renowned smith in the Germanic legends) is the same as Aulë, but Rúmil corrected him, saying rather that ''Wéland'' is actually Velindo.{{PE|15}}, "[[Early Runic Documents]]", ''ER1d: Fourth page'', p. 96 == Etymology == The name ''Velindo'' is in [[Qenya]], with '''''Gwilion''''' being its [[Gnomish]] equivalent - however, their meaning is unclear.{{webcite|author=[[Paul Strack]]|articleurl=http://eldamo.org/content/words/word-2905375421.html|articlename=ᴱQ. ''Velindo'' m.|website=Eldamo|accessed=26 June 2022}} Velindo's name in [[Old English]] was '''''Wéland''''' or '''''Welund'''''. == Other versions of the legendarium == In another contemporary text, the Germanic smith Wéland is instead identified with the [[Gnomes|Gnome]] [[Fëanor]]. That text depicts an outline of a story placed during the wars of the Elves with [[Melko]], in which Fëanor was captured by a man called [[Niðad]],In the text as originally written, ''Niðad'' was a replacement for ''Melko'', and the ''Niaroth'' for ''Orcs''. King of the [[Niaroth]]. However, Fëanor killed Niðad's sonsIn the original text, Fëanor killed Melko's "captain of orcs", instead of Niðad's sons. and managed to escape by crafting artificial wings for himself; he also made love to the king's daughter [[Beaduhilde]] and fled with her, but ultimately lost her in woods. Eventually Beaduhilde (who was now pregnant) forgave Fëanor, and in spite of her father's wrath at her pregnancy, she still managed to obtain Niðad's blessing upon her son.{{PE|15}}, "[[Early Runic Documents]]", ''ER1f: Sixth and seventh pages'', p. 97 == See also == *[[Fëanor#Other versions of the legendarium|Fëanor]] == External links == *"[https://scholar.valpo.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1381&context=journaloftolkienresearch Skilled Smiths and Princes of Elves: The Wayland-legend and the First Age of Middle-earth]" by Lillian Hammen in the second issue of Volume 9 of the Journel of Tolkien Research {{references|notes}} [[Category:Characters in The Book of Lost Tales]] [[Category:Fays]] [[Category:Qenya names]] [[Category:Smiths]]
